p.text: [heading am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[69], effective 1 January 2009]
This section applies to evidence of a kind that may be unreliable, including the following kinds of evidence:
evidence in relation to which Part 3.2 (hearsay evidence) or 3.4 (admissions) applies,
identification evidence,
evidence the reliability of which may be affected by age, ill health (whether physical or mental), injury or the like,
evidence given in a criminal proceeding by a witness, being a witness who might reasonably be supposed to have been criminally concerned in the events giving rise to the proceeding,
evidence given in a criminal proceeding by a witness who is a prison informer,
oral evidence of questioning by an investigating official of a defendant that is questioning recorded in writing that has not been signed, or otherwise acknowledged in writing, by the defendant,

in a proceeding against the estate of a deceased person — evidence adduced by or on behalf of a person seeking relief in the proceeding that is evidence about a matter about which the deceased person could have given evidence if he or she were alive.
[subs (1) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[70], effective 1 January 2009]
If there is a jury and a party so requests, the judge is to:
warn the jury that the evidence may be unreliable, and
inform the jury of matters that may cause it to be unreliable, and
warn the jury of the need for caution in determining whether to accept the evidence and the weight to be given to it.
The judge need not comply with subsection (2) if there are good reasons for not doing so.
It is not necessary that a particular form of words be used in giving the warning or information.
This section does not affect any other power of the judge to give a warning to, or to inform, the jury.

Subsection (2) does not permit a judge to warn or inform a jury in proceedings before it in which a child gives evidence that the reliability of the child’s evidence may be affected by the age of the child. Any such warning or information may be given only in accordance with section 165A(2) and (3) .
[subs (6) subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[71], effective 1 January 2009]
The Commonwealth Act does not include subsection (6) .
[s 165 am Act 109 of 2001 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 26 July 2002]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 1015, 1017–1020
ALRC 38 paras 238–239
Legislation cited in [51,550.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

The provisions of the section confer a discretion upon the trial judge to warn wherever the evidence is of a kind that may be unreliable: R v Stewart (2001) 52 NSWLR 301; 124 A Crim R 371; [2001] NSWCCA 260; BC200105232 .

Section 165 does not deal with the general grounds on which the evidence of a witness might be challenged: R v Vulovic (No 3) [2012] NSWSC 211; BC201201250 . Rather see R v Baartman [2000] NSWCCA 298; BC200005447 ; GAR v R (No 2) [2010] NSWCCA 164; BC201005452 . Accordingly, it is not necessary for a trial judge to give a warning about the honesty of a witness, unless the witness falls into one of the categories set out in the section. General issues of witness credibility (vagueness, inconsistency, motives to lie or demeanour) are not matters of “unreliability” to which the section applies: Stojcevski v R [2012] NSWCCA 27; BC201201000 ; R v Fowler (2003) 151 A Crim R 166; [2003] NSWCCA 321; BC200307077 . It is for the trial judge to determine whether the evidence falls within one of the paragraphs of s 165(1) (see Mazzitelli v R (2002) 135 A Crim R 132; [2002] NSWCCA 436; BC200206509 ).

As to evidence which is unreliable having regard to the provisions of s 165(1)(c) see Toohey v Metropolitan Police Cmr [1965] AC 595 ; Bromley v R (1986) 161 CLR 315 at 320; 67 ALR 12 ; Longman v R (1989) 89 ALR 161 at 166 and 182 ; as to accomplices ( s 165(1)(d) ) see R v Baskerville [1916] 2 KB 658 at 665; Davies v DPP [1954] AC 378 at 400 ; R v Galuzzo (1986) 23 A Crim R 211 at 213 ; R v Checconi (1988) 34 A Crim R 160 at 167 .

The warning referred to in s 165(2) need not follow any particular formula but must be cogent, effective and appropriate to the circumstances of the particular case: Domican v R (1992) 173 CLR 555; 106 ALR 203; BC9202665 ; R v Clarke (1997) 97 A Crim R 414; BC9705745 ; R v Eldridge [2002] NSWCCA 205; BC200202865 ; R v Stewart (above); R v Yammine (2002) 132 A Crim R 44; [2002] NSWCCA 289; BC200204077 ; R v Sullivan [2003] NSWCCA 100; BC200301699 . In general terms, where the evidence falls within one of the stipulated categories, the jury should be made aware of the need for both a close analysis of the evidence, as well as the need for caution in determining whether to accept it, and to the weight that they should give to it. If a warning under s 165(2) is given that hearsay evidence “may” be unreliable, the jury should be left to determine the issue of weight actually given to the hearsay evidence. The judge should not give any inference or direction in that regard: R v Wilson (2005) 62 NSWLR 346; [2005] NSWCCA 20 at [34]; BC200500719 .

Once a determination is made that the section applies, the trial judge must comply with the directives set out: (R v Nguyen [2002] NSWSC 1254; BC200208142 ); unless they come to the conclusion that there are “good reasons” for not doing so. “Good reasons” include satisfaction that the matter can be adequately dealt with by detailed directions, as opposed to a warning: R v Flood [1999] NSWCCA 198; BC9904096 . Although the terms of the section do not specifically require trial judges to give reasons for declining to give a warning, it is generally desirable that reasons be given: see R v Beattie (1996) 40 NSWLR 155; 89 A Crim R 393; BC9604282 ; R v Taranto [1999] NSWCCA 396; BC9908460 ; R v Mayberry [2000] NSWCCA 531; BC200007665 ; R v TJF (2001) 120 A Crim R 209; [2001] NSWCCA 127; BC200101671 ; Kutschera v R [2010] NSWCCA 150; BC201004959 at [95] and following (appeal based on inadequacy of s 165 warning given by trial judge — appeal dismissed); R v Vulovic (No 3) [2012] NSWSC 211; BC201201250 at [24] and following (good reasons for not giving a warning). Where an accused has not given evidence and the Crown has led hearsay evidence given by the accused to the police when interviewed, it will be for the trial judge to determine whether the accused’s decision not to give evidence is a “good reason” in that particular case: R v Wilson (2005) 62 NSWLR 346; [2005] NSWCCA 20 at [37]; BC200500719 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,555] s 165A Warnings in relation to children’s evidence

leg:heading.title: Warnings in relation to children’s evidence

p.text: A judge in any proceeding in which evidence is given by a child before a jury must not do any of the following:
warn the jury, or suggest to the jury, that children as a class are unreliable witnesses,
warn the jury, or suggest to the jury, that the evidence of children as a class is inherently less credible or reliable, or requires more careful scrutiny, than the evidence of adults,
give a warning, or suggestion to the jury, about the unreliability of the particular child’s evidence solely on account of the age of the child,
in the case of a criminal proceeding — give a general warning to the jury of the danger of convicting on the uncorroborated evidence of a witness who is a child.
Subsection (1) does not prevent the judge, at the request of a party, from:
informing the jury that the evidence of the particular child may be unreliable and the reasons why it may be unreliable, and
warning or informing the jury of the need for caution in determining whether to accept the evidence of the particular child and the weight to be given to it,

if the party has satisfied the court that there are circumstances (other than solely the age of the child) particular to the child that affect the reliability of the child’s evidence and that warrant the giving of a warning or the information.
This section does not affect any other power of a judge to give a warning to, or to inform, the jury.
[s 165A subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[72], effective 1 January 2009]
This section applies in a criminal proceeding in which there is a jury.

If the court, on application by a party, is satisfied that the defendant has suffered a significant forensic disadvantage because of the consequences of delay, the court must inform the jury of the nature of that disadvantage and the need to take that disadvantage into account when considering the evidence.
The judge need not comply with subsection (2) if there are good reasons for not doing so.

It is not necessary that a particular form of words be used in informing the jury of the nature of the significant forensic disadvantage suffered and the need to take that disadvantage into account, but the judge must not in any way suggest to the jury that it would be dangerous or unsafe to convict the defendant solely because of the delay or the forensic disadvantage suffered because of the consequences of the delay.

The judge must not warn or inform the jury about any forensic disadvantage the defendant may have suffered because of delay except in accordance with this section, but this section does not affect any other power of the judge to give any warning to, or to inform, the jury.
For the purposes of this section:
delay includes delay between the alleged offence and its being reported, and
significant forensic disadvantage is not to be regarded as being established by the mere existence of a delay.
For the purposes of this section, the factors that may be regarded as establishing a significant forensic disadvantage include, but are not limited to, the following:
the fact that any potential witnesses have died or are not able to be located,
the fact that any potential evidence has been lost or is otherwise unavailable.
[s 165B subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[72], effective 1 January 2009]
